Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Understanding the diversity and evolution of flattended amoebas within "Discosea" using phylogenomics and cytoskeletal architecture

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Spelman College has potential broader impact in a number of areas. Members of the supergroup Amoebozoa, which are to be studied in this project, are among the most abundant microorganisms globally. They play a major role in maintaining ecosystems and cause significant health problems for humans. Yet, their diversity and taxonomy are poorly known, which hinders applications in ecological and medical studies.
This project will also enhance the research experience and training of undergraduate students a Spelman College.

Most microbial amoeboid lineages fall within two major eukaryotic clades: Amoebozoa and Rhizaria. This project focuses on the relationships among the lineages of Amoebozoa, which are poorly resolved. This is mainly due to paucity and plasticity of morphological characters and limited sampling of genetic data. The project seeks to understand the evolution of one of the subgroups of Amoebozoa, Discosea, using large genetic data and refined analyses of pseudopodia architecture employing a novel method. Discosea encompasses flattened naked amoebas with the most diverse morphotypes. The Discosea is loosely defined by morphological data and has never been recovered in any molecular phylogenetic studies. Both increased genetic data and proteome level pseudopodial characters will allow reconstruction of a robust phylogeny and thorough morphological homology assessment within the group. Specific objectives of this project are to generate transcriptomes from eight core representatives of Discosea; obtain novel morphological data on cytoskeletal structures using immunocytochemistry and confocal fluorescence microscopy; and test specific phylogenetic hypotheses within the Discosea using large genetic data and morphological characters. Beyond the Discosea phylogeny, the generated genetic data and novel morphological characters will help to give cellular biological insights into specialized cells such as cancer, immune and embryonic cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research aiming to understand the diversity, evolution, and phylogenetic relationships of understudied amoebae, Discosea, belonging to the supergroup Amoebozoa. The supergroup Amoebozoa is one of the eukaryotic major clades (groups) that encompasses the majority of lineages that move and feed using pseudopodia (false feet). It is composed of amoeboid forms, including genera that cause disease in humans such as Entamoeba histolytica (amoebic dysentery) and Acanthamoeba spp. (meningitis and corneal infections), a laboratory-cultured model organism (Dictyostelium, a member of the slime mold group), and free-living forms (e.g. Amoeba proteus). The supergroup holds a key phylogenetic position in the tree of life. It is the only microbial lineage closest to our own clade, Opisthokonta, which includes animals and fungi. Despite its evolutionary significance, the diversity, ecology, and evolution of Amoebozoa and its members remain poorly studied. This is mainly due to a lack of useable morphological characters and limited sampling of genetic data in the group. In this project we investigated the evolution of one of the most contentious subgroups of Amoebozoa, the Discosea, using large-scale genetic (transcriptome) data and refined analyses of pseudopodial architecture using a novel method. The Discosea encompasses disc-shaped, naked amoebae with highly diverse morphotypes. The Discosea is loosely defined by morphological data and has never been recovered in any molecular phylogenetic studies. Both increased genetic data and proteome-level pseudopodial characters have allowed us to reconstruct a robust phylogeny and define groups within the Discosea using newly generated morphological characters.

The proposed projects have resulted in novel and foundational findings that not only helped redefine the target taxa but also generated morphological characters, through a pioneering work, useful in defining major subgroups in the Amoebozoa. Two of our publications that resulted from this project are among the first and largest phylogenomic analysis in the supergroup. These publications helped resolve the phylogeny of the Discosea by uncovering novel relationships and refuting older classification schemes. The large transcriptome data generated in this project also contributed to a publication that showed amoebozoans as ancestrally sexual, debunking long-held views that most amoebae are strictly asexual lineages. One of our publications focused on examining pseudopodia and other cellular features using a novel approach of immunocytochemistry and confocal microscopy. This publication introduced several new morphological characters that were found congruent with the molecular phylogeny. We showed that these newly generated characters could be used to study shallow and deep relationships in the supergroup. This is a significant contribution since the taxonomy of Amoebozoa has stalled for over a century due to paucity of morphological characters. Finally, an undergraduate project resulted in the description of a new amoeba species characterized by high frequency of cellular and nuclear fusion. This project was an extension of a fieldwork from one of our introductory undergraduate courses that involves collection of water samples from nearby lakes.

The project has directly trained 25 African American women undergraduates in diverse techniques including molecular methods, light and fluorescence microcopy, culturing of microbes, immunocytochemistry, bioinformatics tools, data mining, statistical analyses, and field biology. In addition, these participants learned preparation and presentation of scientific reports. Parts of the projects have been integrated into introductory and upper-level electives, which resulted in educational videos and presentations of mini-projects in class. The educational videos and practical water sample exercises were used to teach local middle and high school students to provide them with preparatory college experience as well as basic scientific hands-on, inquiry-based laboratory experiences on freshwater microbial diversity. The project generated large amounts of genetic data critical for further analysis of the amoebozoans. We also deposited live cultures of the newly described amoeba in a culture collection agency that can be useful for future work.
